title: How hard is Chopin’s Fantaisie-Impromptu? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll answer from my perspective. I’ve played by ear my whole life, never took piano lessons ever. I learned to read music by playing Oboe in middle school and high school, and eventually translated that to learning to read piano sheet music. Eventually I sucked it up and googled the fingerings for scales and started practicing those. I’ve researched some technique, and it’s definitely helped me become a much better pianist. But again, never took 1 minute worth of piano lessons. That being said, I sat down and took a stab at Fantaisie-Impromptu. It sounded intimidating at first. But, the version of sheet music I had put the finger numbers over each note. So I basically just used the fingering suggested, and within like 2 weeks, I could basically play it, albeit not at performance level. I still mess up certain passages a little bit, but that can mostly be attributed to rushing and sloppiness. To be honest, I’ve played much more difficult pieces than this, most of which aren’t even classical. I don’t know why this ends up on like top 10 lists and everything of “hardest songs ever”. One particular reason I’m always dumbfounded by this claim is that if you pay attention, there is not one single chord played on the right hand, until the last measure. This means after every note, you have more (feasible) options of what finger to choose for the next note. Songs become much more difficult when you’ve got multiple melody lines with chords and arpeggios mixed together. Fingerings become awkward, and achieving the desired dynamic can be really challenging when you’re fighting that. It’s not really as much of an issue in this song. tl;dr: From my perspective as basically an amateur who never took real lessons (but can read music and plays for fun), this piece isn’t as hard as it might seem. There are no chords on the right hand, and if you get a version with the fingerings written in, just follow that and you should be able to play it.
